explanation:
For MISRA C rule checking (a function parameter shall not be modified — the pointer variable itself must not be altered; objects pointed-to may be):

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro used to obtain 'impl' from token; must be inspected to ensure it does not perform assignments to the 'token' parameter (e.g., via side effects or evaluating '*token' as an lvalue).
- OS_impl_filehandle_table: argument to the macro; the macro implementation may index/expand against this symbol — needed to understand macro expansion and side effects.
- OS_object_token_t: type of the 'token' parameter. Needed to confirm const qualifiers and what '*token' yields (so we can determine whether the code or macros could modify the token object or the pointer variable).
- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: type of 'impl' so we can see fields (selectable, fd) accessed; ensures impl assignment is a plain read and does not imply modification of a parameter.
- OS_SockAddr_t: definition of RemoteAddr structure (AddrData, ActualLength). Required to confirm that writing RemoteAddr->ActualLength modifies the object pointed-to (allowed) and does not modify the RemoteAddr pointer itself (disallowed).
- OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN: constant used to set addrlen; included to check any macro/side-effect usage that could alter parameters (usually constant but included to fully expand addrlen usage).
- struct sockaddr: target type used for 'sa' to ensure casts/takes-of-address do not alter RemoteAddr pointer variable.
- socklen_t: type of addrlen; included to ensure &addrlen use with recvfrom does not imply modification of the RemoteAddr pointer variable.
- OS_SelectSingle_Impl: prototype/definition to confirm it is a function (not a macro) and to check whether any macro wrapper could modify the 'token' parameter variable itself during the call.
- OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE: constant evaluated against 'operation'; included to ensure no macro side effects when used with the 'operation' parameter.
- MSG_DONTWAIT: flag used for waitflags; included to verify no unexpected macro side effects affecting parameter variables.
- recvfrom: prototype to verify how addrlen and sa are passed and to confirm this call cannot modify the local pointer variables (only the objects they point to).
- errno: external variable read to determine error path; include to confirm checks do not modify any parameter variables.
- strerror: used for logging; include to ensure no side effects on parameters.
- OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT, OS_QUEUE_EMPTY, OS_ERROR: return-code macros/constants used for control flow; included to ensure any macro expansions do not reassign parameters.
- OS_DEBUG: logging macro used on error path — included to ensure it is not defined in a way that modifies parameters.

In short: focus on macros and types that reference or dereference the pointer parameters (token, RemoteAddr, buffer) and any callee/macro that might have side-effects on those parameter variables. The above symbols are needed to expand macros and inspect prototypes to conclusively determine whether any parameter variable is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function.
